title: Pule Hill Walking Route

images.title: Martin Clark / Pule Hill
images.caption: Pule Hill. Looking north to Pule Hill (437m) from Mount Road, near Marsden, West Yorkshire.

images.title: Colin Fraser / Pule Hill
images.caption: Pule Hill with Standedge Trail at the foot, taken from Blacker Edge on A640

images.title: Raymond Knapman / Railway and canal from Pule Hill
images.caption: Railway and canal from the hill. The railway and canal enter their tunnels below the A62 and the hill

images.title: Humphrey Bolton / View from the summit of Pule Hill, Marsden
images.caption: View from the summit of Pule Hill, Marsden. No triangulation pillar to mark this summit. The nominal subject is the small blue pond just to the right of centre. This is marked 'well' on my six-inch map, and is next to Mount Road.

images.title: Humphrey Bolton / Track past the air shafts, Pule Holes, Marsden
images.caption: Track past the air shafts, Pule Holes, Marsden. This is the easiest way up onto Pule Hill; it climbs relatively gently up the edge of the escarpment and then continues to the air shaft at SE036115, but turning southwards along the edge, the summit is soon reached.

images.title: Humphrey Bolton / Tunnel vent shaft and spoil heap, Pule Edge, Marsden
images.caption: Tunnel vent shaft and spoil heap, Pule Edge, Marsden

images.title: Raymond Knapman / Heritage centre at Marsden
images.caption: Heritage centre at Marsden. View from towpath on Huddersfield Narrow Canal

images.title: Stephen Craven / Looking over Netherley towards Butterley Reservoir
images.caption: Looking over Netherley towards Butterley Reservoir

description: This circular walk climbs to Pule Hill on the wonderful Marsden Moor Estate in the South Pennines. The route runs for about 5 miles with a fairly challenging climb on the way. Start the walk from Marsden train station and then pick up footpaths heading west along the canal towards the Standedge Tunnels. Here you can pick up a section of the Standedge Trail and follow it south, crossing the route of the Huddersfield Narrow Canal as you go. From the high points there are some splendid views across the Pennines and down to Redbrook Reservoir below. You continue round to the east and north along the trail before coming to Netherley where you can visit Butterley Reservoir. The route then picks up the Kirklees Way and follows the waymarked trail back to the train station.
